When I learned Michael Brown was shot six times in ‘self-defense’ not only 
did I realize that EUA’s and Brazil’s police and justice are more alike 
than different, I also felt the urge to translate the following text on the 
same subject, prompted by a much older crime.

Mineirinho 

(The nick means little guy from Minas Gerais, a Brazilian state. A famous 
criminal killed in the 60’s, during an operation involving 300 officers in 
Rio de Janeiro. Although a violent killer and robber, he was beloved at his 
community for helping needy locals. Clarice Lispector, one of the main 20th 
century Brazilian writers – so I’m probably breeching some copyright law 
here -, wrote the following right after his death. Feel free to criticize 
the rendering into English, as it’s definitely not my mother tongue.)

So, I suppose it's within myself, while representing all of us, that I 
should look for why is the death of such a criminal hurting so deep. And 
why do I care more for adding up the thirteen shots which killed him than 
for adding up his crimes. I asked my cook what she thought about the fact. 
I saw on her face the little convulsion of a conflict, the uneasiness of 
not understanding what oneself feels, of needing to betray contradictory 
emotions for not knowing how to bring them to harmony. Irreducible facts, 
but irreducible revolt as well, the violent compassion of revolt. Feeling 
oneself divided within one’s own perplexity before the inability to forget 
that Mineirinho was dangerous and had already killed too many; 
nevertehless, we wanted him alive. The cook closed in on herself a little, 
perhaps seeing in me the justice that takes revenge. Somewhat angry at me, 
who was stirring her soul, she coldly replied, ‘What I feel is not worth 
saying. Who doesn’t know the criminal Mineirinho was? Although I’m sure 
he’s been saved and rests in heaven now.’ I answered, ‘more so than many he 
has killed.’ Why? The very first commandment, which protects body and 
irreplaceable life, is that thou shalt not kill. It is my greatest 
guaranty: therefore I’m not killed, for I don’t want to die, and therefore 
they don’t let me kill, for killing will be my darkness.
That is the law. But there’s something which, if it makes me hear the first 
and second shots with relief, at safe, at the third I’m alert, at the 
fourth, unquiet, the fifth and the sixth encumber me with shame, the 
seventh and the eighth I hear with my heart beating in horror, the ninth 
and the tenth find my mouth trembling, the eleventh makes me utter in awe 
the name of the Lord, at the twelfth I cry for my brother. The thirteenth 
murders me - for I am the other. Because I want to be the other.
Such justice holds wake for my sleep, I repudiate it, humiliated by my 
dependence on it. Meanwhile I sleep and find a fake redemption. Us, the 
essential hypocrites.
So that my household will function, I demand from myself as first duty 
being hypocrite, and that I do not exert my revolt and my love, both put 
away. If I am not hypocrite, my house is shaken. I must have forgotten that 
underneath my house stands the ground, the base on which a new house might 
be built. Meanwhile we sleep and find our fake redemption. 
Till thirteen shots wake us up, and in horror I say, too late - 
twenty-eight years after Mineirinho was born -, that the cornered man 
should not be killed for our sake. Because I know he is my mistake. And 
from a whole life, by God, sometimes only the mistake is saved, and I know 
we’ll not save ourselves till our mistake hasn’t become precious to us. My 
error is my mirror, where I watch in silence what I have done to a man. My 
mistake is the way I saw life open itself in its flesh and wondered, and 
saw the matter of life, placenta and blood, the living mud.
In Mineirinho my way of life has burst. How not to love him, when he lived 
to the thierteenth shot what I was sleeping? His frightened violence. His 
innocent violence - not in its consequences, but innocent within itself, as 
that of a child not taken care by his father.
All which was violence in him, in us is furtive, and we avoid facing each 
other, to avoid the risk of understanding. So that the house won’t be 
shaken.
The blown violence in Mineirinho, wich only another of man’s hands, the 
hand of hope, sitting on his stupefied and sick head, would be able to 
sooth, making him finally raise his surprised eyes, at least filled with 
tears. Only after a man is found innert on the ground, with no cap and no 
shoes, I realize I’ve forgotten to say: me too.
I don’t want this house. I want a justice which would give a chance to 
something pure and bleak in Mineirinho - that thing which moves mountains 
and which is the same that made him ‘crazily’ like a woman, the same which 
made him cross so narrow a door that lacerated his bareness; it is 
something in us so intense and limpid as a dangerous gram of radium, that 
thing is a grain of life which, if stepped uppon, turns into something 
threatening – crushed love; that thing, which in Mineirinho became a 
dagger, is the same which makes me give water to another man, not because I 
have water, but because I know, too, what thirst is; and me, too, who 
haven’t fallen, experienced fall.
Previous justice, that wouldn’t disgrace me. It’s high time, with or 
without irony, we were more divine; if we foresee what would the Lord’s 
goodness be, it is because we divine goodness within ourselves, that 
goodness which sees the man before his being ill of crime. I keep hoping, 
although, that God be the father, when I know a man can be another man’s 
father.
And keep living in the fragile house. This house, whose protecting door I 
lock so well, this house which won’t resist the first gale - which will 
blow a locked door in the air. But it stands, and Mineirinho lived the rage 
for me, while I was restful.
He was shot dead in his disoriented strength, while a makeshift god, at the 
last moment, hurriedly blesses my organized evil and brutalized justice: 
what sustains the walls in my house is the certainty that I’ll always 
justify myself - my friends won’t justify me, but my enemies, who are my 
accomplices, those will congratulate me; what sustains me is knowing that 
I’ll always make a god to the image of whatever I need to sleep sound, and 
others will furtively pretend we are all right and that there’s nothing to 
do.
All of it, yes, for we are the essential hypocrites, bastions of something. 
And, above all, we seek not to understand.
For who understands, disorganizes. There is something within us which would 
disorganize everything - something which understands. This thing gets mute 
before the man without the cap and the shoes, who has robbed and killed to 
have them; and gets mute before the Saint George of gold and diamonds. That 
some very serious thing in me gets even more serious before the 
machine-gunned man. Is that thing the murderer within? No, it is despair 
within. Like lunatics, we know him, this dead man in whom the radium gram 
burned in fire. But just as lunatics, not as hypocrites, do we know him. 
It’s as a lunatic that I enter into life, so many times without doors, and 
as a lunatic I understand what is dangerous to understand, and only as a 
lunatic do I feel the deep love, that love which confirms itself when I see 
the radium will irradiate somehow, if not by trust, by hope and by love, 
then miserably by the sick courage to destroy. Were I not a lunatic, I 
would be eight hundred police officers, with eight hundred machine-guns, 
and that would be my honour.
Until a slightly crazier justice came. One which would take into account 
that we all have to speak for a man who despaired, for in him human speech 
has failed, he is so mute that only the brute disarticulated scream will do 
as a signal.
A previous justice which remembered our great struggle is with fear, and 
that a man who kills many, it’s because he had that much fear. Above all a 
justice which would look within itself, and see that all of us, living mud, 
are dark, and therefore nor even a man’s evil may be handed to another 
man’s evil: so that the latter may not freely commit the crime of gunning a 
man with approval.
A justice which wouldn’t forget we are all dangerous, and that at the 
moment a vigilante kills, he is not protecting us anymore, nor willing to 
eliminate a criminal, but commiting his private crime, a long awaited-for 
one. At the moment of killing a criminal, at this very moment an innocent 
is being killed. No, it is not that I long for the sublime, nor the things 
into which the words that make me sleep sound have been turning, a mixture 
of forgiveness, vague charity - us refugees into the abstract.
What I want is much harsher and harder: I want earthlyness.﻿

THE POWER OF STORYTELLING

IS COMPLAINING ENOUGH?

Making life more human is a challenge; an African farmer learned through 
firsthand experiences. One day, a chilly morning, as he walked down toward 
his farm, he spotted a nest on a little tree there. As the nest seemed to 
be shaking a bit; it arose his curiosity. Then, he discovered there was a 
baby bird. How long it was left alone, he wondered. He looked around but 
saw any other bird in perspective, unfortunately. Meanwhile, the baby bird 
kept on shivering. Watching it shivering so sadly triggered his compassion. 
Thus, out of compassion, the farmer took the baby bird and kept it warm in 
his hand. And right away, it stopped shivering.
Subsequently, the farmer began to feel embarrassed and guilty. How long he 
is going to put up with this situation. He has his own commitments. He 
appeared to lament that the incident was not part of his today's agenda. 
But, at the same time, his conscience kept on congratulating him quietly.
Speaking to himself, and without his knowing, he moved closer to one of the 
cows sitting in the farm backyard. Scared probably, the cow feared for its 
life and pooped in the process; before it runs away. All of a sudden, the 
farmer's eyes brightened with joy and relief; and he grinned. He appeared 
to have a better idea; and his subsequent actions proved it: "My beloved 
baby bird, I am relieved and happy to realize that the warmth which 
emanates from this fresh cow manure will help you as well as my hand did. 
Thus, be welcomed and enjoy your day," the farmer said. He dug a little 
hole in the cow manure and put the baby bird in there, carefully. Then, he 
murmured:"you are safe, now".
 But, how could the farmer imagine that he was making it an easy prey for a 
young eagle. The young eagle watched the whole event; now, it was just 
hoping to see the farmer go away. So, as soon as the farmer turned his 
back, the young eagle landed in the cow manure. Consequently, the baby bird 
fatally found its eternal warmth in the young eagle's stomach.
  Meantime, the farmer looked around and saw the young eagle flying away. 
Bitterness surrounded his mind. Suddenly, he inferred the tragic END of the 
baby bird and exclaimed:
1 - The one who PUTS you into trouble, does not necessarily WANT to HURT 
you.
2 - The one who GETS you out of your trouble, does not necessarily WANT or 
WISH your WELL-BEING.
3 - And finally, anyone who finds himself or herself in trouble can no 
longer BE HAPPY.

Actually sad and visibly disappointed, the farmer equated the incident with 
some human tragedies. Out of compassion, he personified the event and came 
up with THREE STARTLING OBSERVATIONS:
- The one who SELLS or GIVES you a weapon (GUN), does not necessarily WANT
to HARM you. (1)
- The one who TAKES your weapon (GUN) away, does not necessarily WANT your 
WELL-BEING. (2)
- And finally, here is the fact. The one who GETS GUNNED DOWN is HURT or 
GONE forever. GUNS just take their SMILE and more essentially their LIFE 
away.
Therefore, Africa and the whole WORLD, the GUN ISSUE can no longer be 
IGNORED and/or TRIVIALIZED. It is just INHUMANE, the farmer lamented as he 
recalled all the victims of "civil wars" and gun violence.
In substance: LIFE IS SO SACRED NOT TO PROTECT.

Story written by Noelle Bizi Bazouma a.k.a bizbanoelle.﻿

"For a crime to exist, there must be an injured party. There can be no

"All codes, rules, and regulations are for government authorities only, not

"All laws, rules and practices which are repugnant to the Constitution are 
null and void" [Marbury v. Madison, 5th US (2 Cranch) 137, 180]

The common law is the real law, the Supreme Law of the land, the code, 
rules, regulations, policy and statutes are “not the law”, [Self v. Rhay, 
61 Wn (2d) 261]

"The general rule is that an unconstitutional statute, though having the 
form and name of law, is in reality no law, but is wholly void and 
ineffective for any purpose, since its unconstitutionality dates from the 
time of its enactment... In legal contemplation, it is as inoperative as if 
it had never been passed... Since an unconstitutional law is void, the 
general principles follow that it imposes no duties, confers no right, 
creates no office, bestows no power or authority on anyone, affords no 
protection and justifies no acts performed under it... A void act cannot be 
legally consistent with a valid one. An unconstitutional law cannot operate 
to supersede any existing law. Indeed insofar as a statute runs counter to 
the fundamental law of the land, (the Constitution) it is superseded 
thereby. No one is bound to obey an unconstitutional law and no courts are 
bound to enforce it." [Bonnett v. Vallier, 116 N.W. 885, 136 Wis. 193 
(1908); NORTON v. SHELBY COUNTY, 118 U.S. 425 (1886)]

"There, every man is independent of all laws, except those prescribed by 
nature. He is not bound by any institutions formed by his fellowman without 
his consent." [Cruden v. Neale, 2 N.C. 338 (1796) 2 S.E.]

"Under our system of government upon the individuality and intelligence of 
the citizen, the state does not claim to control him/her, except as his/her 
conduct to others, leaving him/her the sole judge as to all that affects 
himself/herself." Mugler v. Kansas 123 U.S. 623, 659-60.

"Statutes that violate the plain and obvious principles of common right and 
common reason are null and void." Bennett v. Boggs, 1 Baldw 60.

"The assertion of federal rights, when plainly and reasonably made, is not 
to be defeated under the name of local practice." Davis v. Wechsler, 263 US 
22, at 24

"A State may not impose a charge for the enjoyment of a right granted by 
the Federal Constitution." Murdock v. Pennsylvania, 319 U.S. 105, at 113.

"The State cannot diminish rights of the people." Hertado v. California, 
110 U.S. 516 "The Claim and exercise of a Constitutional Right cannot be 
converted into a crime."-Miller v. U.S. , 230 F 2d 486. 489 "If the state 
converts a liberty into a privilege the citizen can engage in the right

"Laws are made for us; we are not made for the laws." [William Milonoff]

The very meaning of 'sovereignty' is that the decree of the sovereign makes

“Inferior courts” are those whose jurisdiction is limited and special and

Alright, here's the facts I'm seeing as I come across researching them:
1. Mike Brown robbed a store. He was caught on camera doing so.
2. Mike Brown had marijuana in his system at his time of death. His autopsy 
reveals as much.
3. The autopsy also reveals that he had a wound on his hand. Mike Brown's 
blood was found in the police car he was in, and an anonymous source 
reports that it was supposedly caused by a struggle that happened in the 
car between Mike Brown and the policeman's gun.
4. The policeman has gone on record saying that Mike Brown was killed by 
being shot at when after running away, he turned around and charged the 
policeman with his hands in the air, but various witnesses have responded 
in kind saying they saw no charging whatsoever.
5. ALL six bullet wounds accounted for in the autopsy show that he was 
fired upon from his front- meaning all accounts saying he was shot while 
running away are either incomplete or lying.
6. He had no gunpowder residue on him, meaning he was not in close quarters 
when shot at.

Verdict: I could probably see a case for manslaughter here, as the cop was 
far too reckless in his duties and a man died unnecessarily for it, but 
outside of that there's absolutely nothing about this that could be called 
premeditation for a murder charge. Please also note the word "probably"- 
Mike Brown did himself no favors by clearly resisting arrest, robbing a 
store, and getting high before his demise. This is going to be a close one.﻿

Under federal law, a riot is a public disturbance involving an act of 
violence by one or more persons assembled in a group of at least three 
people. Inciting a riot applies to a person who organizes, encourages, or 
participates in a riot. It can apply to one who urges or instigates others 
to riot. According to 18 USCS § 2102 "to incite a riot", or "to organize, 
promote, encourage, participate in, or carry on a riot", includes, but is 
not limited to, urging or instigating other persons to riot, but shall not 
be deemed to mean the mere oral or written (1) advocacy of ideas or (2) 
expression of belief, not involving advocacy of any act or acts of violence 
or assertion of the rightness of, or the right to commit, any such act or 
acts.”﻿

Объединение
 
Усаги сидела на берегу небольшого озера и смотрела на искрящуюся в лунном 
свете воду. Звезды и полная Луна отражались в воде, словно в зеркале.
В голове девушки безостановочно стучало:
«Мы Внешние Воины, и мы защищаем галактику от врагов из далекого Космоса. 
Мы воины Вселенной. Внутренние Воины не должны вмешиваться в эту войну!»
– Харука, Мичиру, Хотару, Сецуна, – прошептала Усаги. – Неужели мы не можем 
объединиться в одну команду ради борьбы со злом?
Она медленно поднялась на ноги. Легкий ветерок развевал её золотистые 
волосы, а лучи лунного света ложились на её голову подобно золотой короне.
Мессия...
Она была Мессией. Мессией Света. Человеком, который спас Землю от Фараона 
Наинети.
– Внешние Воины, – прошептала Сейлор Мун, глядя в небо. – Почему мы не 
можем быть друзьями?
Тем временем, Харука, Мичиру и Сецуна сидели в гостиной их дома.
– Зло собирается в Космосе, - произнесла Сейлор Плутон. – Думаю, будущие 
враги будут ещё страшнее предыдущих.
– Тогда мы должны дать им надлежащий отпор, – сжала кулак Харука.
Дверь в гостиную скрипнула и приоткрылась. Трое воительниц разом 
повернулись. На пороге стояла Хотару. Она была одета в простой фиолетовый 
халат.
-Ты не спишь? – спросила Мичиру. – Тебе приснился плохой сон?
– Нет, – ответила девочка. – Я почувствовала силу Тьмы. Враги собираются 
нанести удар по Земле. Воины должны дать им бой.
– Мы тоже так считаем, – кивнула Мичиру. – И мы готовы...
Она не договорила. Девочка покачала головой:
– Внешние Воины и Внутренние Воины должны объединиться в одну команду, ради 
защиты Земли, Солнечной Системы, принца и принцессы.
– Ты не понимаешь, о чем говоришь, – покачала головой Харука. – Мы никогда 
не сможем объединиться вместе с Внутренними Воинами. Мы намного сильнее их, 
наши силы рассчитаны на то, что сражаться против космического зла и 
погибнуть ради защиты света.
– Сейлор Мун ни за что нам этого не позволит, – добавила Мичиру. – Поэтому 
мы должны находиться подальше от неё и от других воинов.
– Я одинокий Воин Разрушения, – сказала Хотару, – но даже я понимаю, что 
порознь мы ничего не добьемся.
Она подняла вверх правую руку, и легким движением плеч скинула на пол 
халат. Фиолетовые и серебряные языки пламени окружили её гибкую, стройную 
фигуру, и через мгновение перед Внешними Воинами стояла Супер Сейлор 
Сатурн, с Косой Тишины в руках.
– Мы должны объединиться ради защиты Света, – сказала Воительница 
Разрушения. – Мы Внешние Воины – защитники Космоса. Внутренние Воины – 
защитники Галактики. Что страшного в нашем объединении? Ответь мне, Сейлор 
Уран!
Она направила Косу на Харуку. Сейлор Уран была сильной взрослой девушкой, 
но даже она с опаской смотрела на Косу Тишины в руках Хотару. Эта маленькая 
девочка обладала поистине невероятной силой, несмотря на свой беззащитный и 
хрупкий вид.
– Ну-у... – Харука замялась, не зная, что ответить.
– Я так и думала, – Сатурн опустила Косу. – Завтра мы встретимся с 
Внутренними Воинами и поговорим с ними. Мы должны все вместе противостоять 
злу.
Харука поколебалась пару минут, посопела, покашляла, а потом взглянула на 
беспомощные лица Мичиру и Сецуны и с тяжелым вздохом кивнула:
– Хорошо, как скажешь.
На следующий день Внешние Воины пришли в храм Рей. Усаги, Минако, Рей, Ами, 
Мако, Луна и Артемис в недоумении глядели на неожиданных гостей.
– Мы должны поговорить с вами, – сказала Харука.
– О чем? – спросила Усаги.
Вместо ответа Харука подняла руку и скомандовала.
– Уран! Дай мне силу!
– Нептун! Дай мне силу! – поддержала её Мичиру.
– Плутон! Дай мне силу! – присоединилась к ним Сецуна.
– Сатурн – Планета Разрушения! Дай мне силу! – закончила Хотару.
Внешние Воины превратились в Супер Сейлор Воинов. Внутренние переглянулись, 
а потом...
– Марс! Венера! Юпитер! Меркурий! Лунная призма!
– ДАЙ МНЕ СИЛУ!!!
Когда «обмен приветствиями» закончился, Супер Сейлор Уран вышла вперед и 
сказала:
-Внешние Воины решили объединиться с Внутренними для борьбы против Зла.
– Вы это серьезно? – не веря своим ушам, воскликнула Юпитер.
– Абсолютно, – сухо кивнула Уран. – Но после того, как новые враги будут 
повержены, мы вновь разделимся. Воины не должны объединяться.
– Всё равно, – покачала головой Сейлор Мун, приложив руки к сердцу. – Я 
рада, что мы друзья. – Затем она ласково улыбнулась.
– Принцесса... – прошептала Уран.
– Ведь мы друзья, правда? – подошла к ней Сейлор Мун и искреннее посмотрела 
ей в глаза. Харука увидела чистоту и свет в глубинах голубых глаз девушки.
– Уран, – к Небесному Воину подошла Сатурн. – Неужели ты позволишь, чтобы 
эта девушка находилась в опасности каждый раз, когда мы будем отдаляться от 
Внутренних Воинов? Когда-то ты сказала мне, что ради великой цели можно 
принести любые жертвы. И ты однажды пожертвовала Нептуном и собой ради этой 
цели. Я хотел бы задать тебе вопрос, Уран: сможешь ли ты принести в жертву 
Сейлор Мун?
Харука долгим взглядом посмотрела на Хотару, потом вздохнула, опустила 
глаза, подняла голову и улыбнулась в ответ Усаги:
– Нет.
– Значит... – глаза принцессы расширились от радости.
– Мы... друзья, – закончила за неё Уран.

The way I see it, it is terrible that Brown's life has been taken, he made 
some mistakes but they may not have deserved a punishment of death. But 
this world is not perfect. I believe Brown did attack the officer, I am not 
sure if he tried to take his weapon, but I think it is likely. Why attack 
an officer through a window of his cruiser if his intent was only to fight 
him hand to hand? If that was his intent he must expect to have 
repercussions, either maced, tazed, and certainly jail time. And even if he 
wasn't going for the officers weapon, think of this from the officers 
perspective. A 290lbs aggressive young man is attacking the very average 
framed officer certainly not in his prime. The officer has little choice 
but to fear for his life, Brown has already proven he is dangerous and the 
officer does not know how far this guy will go. In the very likely 
situation that the officer was knocked out, what is to stop Brown from 
taking his gun and killing him? For all the officer knows this guy is a 
murdering thug, not because he is black, because he attacked an officer 
through his cruiser window with no regard for the law. I think Wilson had 
every right to fire on him while in the cruiser, outside I am not so sure. 
If Brown was moving slowly and not aggresively, towards Wilson or not, with 
arms up or not, I think he should not have been shot to be killed, he was 
already wounded. But did this wound criple him or further enrage him? If 
Brown was charging Wilson he had every right to be shot. Im not saying he 
should have been shot to death though, but in a situation like that Wilson 
may have still felt he was in imminent danger and had little time to react. 
He may have noticed his previous shot on Brown had little to no effect and 
decided he had to shoot him where he was sure to stop him. I think the lack 
of wounds on Wilson actually supports the claim that Brown was going for 
his weapon. If Browns intent was to fight the officer I think there would 
be more damage to his face because if his intent is to take the weapon he 
is not trying to hurt the officer he is trying to overpower him. 
At the end of the day though I could write a strong case for Brown as well, 
but it really rides on the fact Brown robbed a convience store before this, 
I dont trust him OR his friend. If you give me a reason to doubt Wilson I 
will reconsider my view. But until then I am on the side of Wilson, But I 
am not even close to sure his side of the story is true. I just believe his 
side of the story more then the story of Browns supporters. This is a case 
that as of yet, no one can say for sure if Wilson acted within the law 
except Wilson. But no one can say Brown was an innocent sweat boy...he knew 
how strong he was and he abused this power.﻿

This misquote is a serious one, since the difference between a democracy

The word "republic" comes from the Latin res publica — which means simply

other hand, is derived from the Greek words demos and kratein, which

Tawana Glenda Brawley (born 1972) is an African-American woman from 
Wappingers Falls, New York, who gained notoriety in 1987–88 for falsely 
accusing six white men of having raped her. Brawley's accusations were 
given widespread media attention in part from the involvement of her 
advisers, including the Reverend Al Sharpton and African American attorneys 
Alton H. Maddox, who was disbarred for lying in the Brawley case, and C. 
Vernon Mason, also disbarred. Public response to Brawley's story was at 
first mostly sympathetic.  In December 1987, 1,000 people, including Nation 
of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan, marched through the streets of Newburgh, 
New York, in support of Brawley. Sharpton, Maddox, and Mason generated a 
national media sensation. The three claimed officials all the way up to the 
state government were trying to cover up defendants in the case because 
they were white. Specifically, they named Steven Pagones, an Assistant 
District Attorney in Dutchess County, as one of the rapists, and called him 
a racist, among other accusations.﻿
